q.p: A true Witne≈øs delivereth Souls: but A deceitful Witne≈øs ≈øpeaketh lies.

div.p:
THe Text contains two propo≈øitions. The fir≈øt, a Character of a True Witne≈øs. A True Witne≈øs delivereth ≈øouls. The ≈øecond, a Character of a Deceitful Witne≈øs, A Deceitful Witne≈øs ≈øpeaketh lies. In a late di≈øcour≈øe we ≈øhewed the≈øe Characters to be very proper; and that they are Prophetical as well as Proverbial: The fir≈øt containing a Prophecy of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, of Hed-emeth, the Great Witne≈øs of Truth, who≈øe Office was to deliver Souls. The ≈øecond containing a di≈øtinct Prophecy of the Great Witne≈øs of Deceit, of Antichri≈øt, who, in direct oppo≈øition
to Chri≈øt, comes and is come to de≈øtroy ≈øouls with lies. We a≈ø≈øerted al≈øo that the Hebrew Word, which in the text is rendred A Deceitful Witne≈øs, doth plainly, literally and grammatically ≈øignifie The Lord of Rome. So that the whole text is to be rendered thus verbatim according to the Hebrew. The Witne≈øs of Truth delivereth Souls; but the Lord of Rome ≈øpeaketh lies. This thing I onely toucht occa≈øionally in that di≈øcour≈øe, my de≈øign then being to ju≈øtifie the Character and prophecy of the Witne≈øs of Truth; which having done, I think it nece≈ø≈øary by a peculiar di≈øcour≈øe to clear that A≈ø≈øertion; both for mine own ≈øake, becau≈øe it is my A≈ø≈øertion, and I think a≈ø≈øerted by none before: and al≈øo for your ≈øake, that they whom I ≈øuppo≈øe to de≈øire more certain knowledge of the truth of that A≈ø≈øertion, may, as much as lieth in me, be fully ≈øatisfied therein: But chiefly for the Truth's ≈øake, which hereby will greatly be advantag'd; when the fal≈øe Witne≈øs ≈øhall be found ≈øo di≈øtinctly reveal'd. For if we can make it plain, that the Holy Gho≈øt has couched this Truth in this Proverb, and has by the pen of Solomon di≈øtinctly nam'd the Lord of Rome as the Deceitful Witne≈øs that ≈øpeaketh lies, and that in direct oppo≈øition to the Witne≈øs of Truth that delivereth Souls; if this be made plain,
it will put an end to all Controver≈øies between other Churches and Rome. For the Lord of Rome will not only forfeit his Infallibility, that great Shield of his Papacy and Supremacy; but the World too will deny him to be the Vicar of Chri≈øt, and will look upon him as the Great Antichri≈øt, and, next to Satan, the Father of lies. This will certainly come to pa≈øs, if men can once read in expre≈øs terms of Solomon, that as the true Witne≈øs, which is Chri≈øt, delivereth Souls; ≈øo the Lord of Rome ≈øpeaketh lies. Now this, with the help of That True Witne≈øs, we ≈øhall ≈øhew undeniably, not conjecturally, to be the expre≈øs terms of Solomon, expre≈øt with all the Circum≈øtances of Wi≈ødom and Truth that became that Spirit by which Solomon wrote or ≈øpoke. To the full proof whereof, premi≈øe we,

1. That though the Di≈øcovery be clear and evident to tho≈øe that can be brought to under≈øtand, yet it mu≈øt not nece≈ø≈øarily be evident to all that hear; for all that hear cannot be brought to under≈øtand. So the Di≈øcovery of the New World of America was pre≈øently evident to all that Columbus could bring thither to ≈øee that World; but mo≈øt of other men, who would not go to ≈øee it, would not pre≈øently believe it; but now that ≈øo many have ≈øeen
it, I think almo≈øt all men believe it. So I ≈øhall do my endeavour to bring men to the knowledge of this Truth, that by their own under≈øtanding it may be evident to them, as it is evident to me; and when it is evident to Many, the re≈øt will believe as they ought.

2. When the thing is di≈øcover'd, it will be certain and evident, as we have ju≈øt now ≈øaid: but the Di≈øcovery mu≈øt not be ea≈øie nor obvious, nor therefore to be rejected becau≈øe never yet made. This is plain in re≈øpect of all Prophecies, as Chri≈øt ob≈øerv'd to his Apo≈øtles, Mat. 24.15. ≈øpeaking of Daniels Prophecy of the Abomination of de≈øolation; Who≈øo readeth, ≈øaith Chri≈øt, let him under≈øtand. As if Chri≈øt had ≈øaid, Many have read that Prophecy, and you have read it, but who hath under≈øtood it? None; but I tell ye now plainly, that it is the utter De≈øtruction of Jeru≈øalem, which you ≈øhall live to ≈øee. Even ≈øo; many have read this Prophecy of Solomon, but it follows not that any hath under≈øtood it, till the appointed time, which I ≈øhall ≈øhew ye, is now. But this Prophetical ob≈øcurity is mo≈øt peculiar to our ca≈øe, which contains the Di≈øcovery of the Name of Antichri≈øt, and of the Number of his Name. For of this very thing, it is written by the Prophet
him≈øelf, who ≈øpeaks mo≈øt of this matter, Rev. 13.18. Here is wi≈ødom, ≈øays the Great Prophet John. Let him that hath under≈øtanding count the Number, &c. Beloved, be ye ≈øo far from expecting ≈øomething obvious to every man that readeth; that rather reject ye this A≈ø≈øertion, if ye find not both Wi≈ødom and Under≈øtanding in it; yet not my wi≈ødom, or the wi≈ødom of man; but the wi≈ødom of the Holy Gho≈øt, who knew how to couch ≈øo valuable a Prophecy under the contemptible covert of a ≈øingle term of Solomon: And now to di≈øcover it by a contemptible In≈øtrument, when the very time calls for it. Nay, not the Wi≈ødom only, but the Goodne≈øs of God is apparent in the≈øe long concealments of prophetical Truths, and the open Revelation of them in their proper times. For in≈øtance, had Solomon writ in vulgar and obvious terms, that the Lord of Rome ≈øpeaketh lies; Then had Solomon's Books at lea≈øt, if not all the old Scriptures, been burnt by the Lords of Rome, without ≈øome extraordinary Miracles of pre≈øervation, which did not ≈øo become divine Wi≈ødom, who knew how to order the matter better without them. Again, had Solomon writ this in terms obvious to every Reader, or had it been di≈øcover'd before the
time; then ≈øuch Lords of Rome as have been Witne≈ø≈øes of Truth, had been branded with an undue Character: Now then is the time, that this Prophecy ≈øhould be di≈øcover'd, and fir≈øt here in England; for here fir≈øt, by the mo≈øt wonderful Di≈øcoveries that ever were made in the world, the Lord of Rome appears to be indeed, that Great Witne≈øs of deceit who ≈øpeaketh lies, and by Lies de≈øtroyeth tho≈øe Souls which the great Witne≈øs of Truth came to deliver.

Proceed we directly to the Di≈øcovery. The thing to be di≈øcovered lyes hid in the Hebrew term, which in the Text is render'd A deceitful Witne≈øs. The Hebrew term is in the fir≈øt Original written with the≈øe four letters onely, M. R. M. H: Now the Hebrews, till above four hundred years after Chri≈øt, writ no Vowels in their words, as a, e, i, o, or u, but writ the Con≈øonants only, and under≈øtood the Vowels. Which Cu≈øtom of that Language God him≈øelf was the Author of, when he gave his Law to Mo≈øes written without di≈øtinction of Vowels: and I cannot doubt but the Divine Wi≈ødom appointed it ≈øo, to this very end, that many things and prophecies might lye hid in that ob≈øcure Writing, till a proper time to be di≈øcover'd. And ≈øo it came to pa≈øs; for the
Chri≈øtians, di≈øcovering daily more and more te≈øtimonies of the Truth from the Old Scriptures, and confounding the ob≈øtinate Jews with their own writings; the Ma≈øorethans, that they might either change or ob≈øcure ≈øuch places in Scripture as plainly made for the Chri≈øtians again≈øt them, found out this trick of writing Vowels, [which however in it ≈øelf a perfection of writing, yet was in them but a trick of corrupting]: and ≈øeveral places, which they could not corrupt, they utterly rejected, even the whole Book of Daniel; and con≈øulted to ≈øerve I≈øaiah ≈øo, but publick ≈øhame could not permit that. But Prophecies of the nature of the Text, which lay hid in clo≈øe Coverts of words admitting another vulgar ≈øence, as this word Mirmah doth; ≈øuch they could not attempt to change; for they could not ≈øu≈øpect any prophecy in them: and I know there are more in the Scripture, and there may be many more which I know not, in which the Wi≈ødom of God ≈øhines wonderfully to him that under≈øtandeth, and his gracious Providence to pre≈øerve his Truth from them that would ≈øuppre≈øs it utterly, were it in their skill and power. The≈øe Ma≈øorethans added their points and vowels to all the Words, of the Old Te≈øtament,
Ann. Chr. 479. twelve hundred years agoe at the mo≈øt. From this,

'Tis plain, that the Vowels of this word Mirmah are not of Divine Authority, unle≈øs we have other authority than that of the Ma≈øorethans. But the Letters of the word being originally written by Solomon are of Divine Authority, that is, M. R. M. H: which Letters according to the exact analogy of the Hebrew reading, make the entire word of Maromah, of which Mirmah is only a contraction: for the Word Maromah gives every letter its Vowel; but the word Mirmah ca≈øts out the middle-vowel, O, from the letter R, and for the long vowel, A, puts the ≈øhort vowel i, and ≈øo draws together three Syllables into two; Maromah into Mirmah. So that the whole difference is from the Vowels only, which, as all confe≈øs, are not Divine Scripture. If then the Letters, which are certainly of Divine authority, contain in them a more profitable Truth, than what is expre≈øt by the Ma≈øorethans pointing of it; and if that Truth be plainly confirm'd by other Scriptures; then without all doubt we ought to embrace that Truth, and to u≈øe the words of the Holy Gho≈øt to the greate≈øt advantage of it. So, ≈øeeing the Scripture of the
Holy Gho≈øt is really and literally Maromah as well as Mirmah, we may read Maromah as well as Mirmah; yea, rather Maromah than Mirmah, if Maromah be more ≈øignificant and conform to the Holy Gho≈øt in the other Scriptures, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew it is. We reject not the word Mirmah; no; But

We preferre the Word Maromah, for rea≈øons to be given: and we retain the word Mirmah, which in its vulgar u≈øe ≈øignifies Deceit; and ≈øo was a mo≈øt fit word to conceal the Prophecy included in Maromah, which Mirmah too includes in its radical ≈øignification; yea, is the ≈øame Word e≈ø≈øentially with Maromah, and is the ≈øame word, letter for letter, in the Original writing of Solomon, which was the writing of the Holy Gho≈øt: It was nece≈ø≈øary then it ≈øhould be read Mirmah, till the di≈øcovery of the Prophecy of Maromah contained in it. But when the Kernel mu≈øt be produced, then the Shell mu≈øt be broken. Then leave we Mirmah as the Shell; and prove we the property of Maromah.

Maromah, literally and grammatically, according to exact Lexico-graphy and Etymology of the Hebrew tongue; and which is more, according to the ≈øtyle of the Prophets, Old and New, ≈øignifies the Lord of Rome.

I will fir≈øt prove the grammatical, and then the prophetical ≈øignification of the Word. The Grammatical ≈øignification is apparent three wayes; all as plain as Grammatical things can be, only, as was premi≈øed, it mu≈øt not be Obvious to Every Grammarian, nor to be read in the School-Dictionary; for then where's the My≈øtery? of which it is ≈øaid, Let him, that readeth, under≈øtand. And here is Wi≈ødom. And let him, that under≈øtandeth, count the Number, &c. But you ≈øhall ≈øee the Wi≈ødom of God ≈øhine out from a ≈øingle word; even from this word of Maromah. Only have patience, and de≈øpi≈øe not ≈ømall things, which the wi≈øe God makes choice of to confound the things that are great.

And fir≈øt, to fore≈øhew the Lord of Rome, which is ≈øpiritually Babylon, the Spirit would u≈øe a Babylonian word; for Maromah is an Hebrew word in the Babylonian Dialect; for Mar, ≈øays Buxtorfius, is Vox babylonica, and ≈øignifies a Supreme Lord, and is often u≈øed by the Rabbies, ≈øayes the ≈øame Buxtorfius, for Bahal, or Adon: and not only by the Rabbies, but by the Holy Gho≈øt too, both in the Old and New Prophets, Dan. 2.47. Maremalchin, a Babylonian word, for the Lord of Kings, 1 Cor. 16.22. Maranatha, a Babylonian word, for the Lord cometh: Even ≈øo
Maromah, for the Lord of Rome. For Rome is Originally a Hebrew word, and the Hebrews have no other word for Rome, but Roum in the Hebrew Dialect, and Romah in the Babylonian or Chaldaick dialect, whence comes the Greek word RomŒ∑, with an Œ∑ in the end; which an≈øwers the Hebrews He; and from the Greek came the Latin word, by turning Œ∑ into a, as in cena, mu≈øa, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch. Indeed the Greek and Latin tongues come originally from the Hebrew, as Arpenius has learnedly ≈øhown; but e≈øpecially this word Rome came from the Hebrew, as will better appear by the con≈øideration of the Hebrew, Roum, which you may ≈øee in every Lexicon.

Roum is an Hebrew Verb, and ≈øignifies to be High and exalted, or to exalt Ones-≈øelf in place, power, and pride, or to u≈øurp high and great things, chiefly indeed it is ≈øpoken of the exaltation of God above all, as P≈øal. 46.10. Know that I am God, ≈øays the Lord; I will be exalted among the Heathen, I will be exalted in the earth. Aroum baggojim, aroum baarets. But ≈øecondarily, the word is u≈øed, for the pride, ambition and u≈øurpation of men, as we ≈øhall ≈øee. From the Verb Roum come the Sub≈øtantives, Roum, and Romah; both which ≈øignifie Height
in place, power, or pride, from which certainly comes the name of the City of Rome. From the ≈øame Verb you have al≈øo Maroum, which is the principal Word we look for, and you have it in every Hebrew Lexicon. See Buxtorfius in the Radix Roum. Now the commonly receiv'd ≈øignification of Maroum, in the Lexicons, is, The high One of the Earth, or the High thing of the Earth; to which if ye joyn the fir≈øt Etymology, in which is ≈øhewn that Mar is an u≈øual term for Lord; then it will appear plainly that Maroum, as Maromah, ≈øignifies literally and grammatically the Lord of Rome. For as it appears in Buxtorfius, in the Radix Roum, that the Sub≈øtantives Roum, and Romah, are all One; ≈øo it mu≈øt needs be equally plain, that Maroum, and Maromah, are all One.

But if ye ask, which of the≈øe is the proper and Original Word? Maroum certainly with Vau-cholam, is the Original Hebrew word in the Hebrew dialect; and Maromah in the Chaldean or Babylonian dialect. The Pronunciation of Vau-cholam is certainly very hard, and I think quite lo≈øt among the Hebrews them≈øelves: but as for the Greeks and Latins, who have no Vau-cholam in their Language, neither can
pronounce it; the Greeks are forced to take an Œ∑ in the end, and for Roum ≈øay RomŒ∑: the Latins take an a, and ≈øay Roma; the Engli≈øh take an e quie≈øcent and ≈øay Rome. And all becau≈øe of the difficulty of pronouncing Vau-cholam in the word Roum, or rather Rovm. After the ≈øame manner the Original Word, Maroum, with Vau-cholam, is after the Greek fa≈øhion, Maromeh; after the Latin, Maromah; after the Engli≈øh, Marome, with an e quie≈øcent; all which alters not the ≈øignification of the word, but the pronunciation of it only. So homo in Latine is made huomo in Italian, Hombre in Spani≈øh, un homme in French, yet all are Originally the ≈øame word with homo, a man. Much more ea≈øie is it to conceive Maroum and Maromah, to be the ≈øame word in the Hebrew tongue, which counts not the difference of Vowels, nor of accidental, but chiefly of e≈ø≈øential or radical letters. For which,

Ob≈øerve, that the Radix Roum has two cognate and collateral Radixes, one on one ≈øide, and the other on the other: That is, Marah and Ramah. Marah with an Aleph, whence comes Mar a Lord, or one that exalts him≈øelf, has the ≈øame ≈øignification with Roum, to exalt it ≈øelf: but Marah with an He, ≈øignifies to Rebell,
which is a thing con≈øequent to pride.
